The newly inaugurated June
Week Drawing will be held in
front of the Barn today, at
1145. This drawing has
taken the place of the traditional tag week held in former
years. However, instead of
paying a dollar as formerly
and receiving no realm, the
students are asked for only
twenty-five cents and at the same time obtain a chance of
winning a suit or topc,ndt. 'A
disinterested Coed' will be
selected to name at random
one of the numbers sold, that
number being the winner.

EDITORIALS

According to Dr. Dean F. Smiley.
head of the Department of Hygiene
and Preventative 'Aledicine at Cornell University, the health of college students trends downward from
the time they enter, colleges as
freshmen until they leave. Dr.
Smiley explains this by saying that
each year that a man is in college
he takes less and less care of himself. The doctor his arrived at
three causes for this. The first is
that the influence of hnme and
mother is usually strong for good
health habits and maiitenance. The
longer the student, is away from that
influence, the less he feels its effect.
Secondly, that student life has for
many years been notable for it neglect of the ordinary hygienic laws.
There are too 'many bull-sessions
lasting far into the night and morning and too many bouts'of excessive
drinking. Thirdly, says Dr. Smiley,
a fair number of college students
are attempting the physical impossibility of doing the work of two men,
living the life of a day laborer to
earn a living, and the life of a student to acquire an education.
We notice the fact that, sad as it
may seem, although Dr. Smiley has
told us our defects he has not suggested any means by which we may
better these conditions. ,

Richmond, Va.,
Dear Sir:
Going to take the pleasure and drop
you a few lines to say that my favorite
tobacco is your Edgeworth. I have
been a user of it for the last eight
years and find it's the only tobacco
for a real good smoke.
For the last five or six months I
have been trying several other kinds
but I find Edgeworth is the only
tobacco for me.
If I am smoking any other brand
my wife will tell me, as sh4ikec the
smell of only Edgeworth. When I'm
smoking others she opens 01 windows
and doors.
The reason for writing this letter
is that I had a card party last night,
and moett all of the party asked me
what kind of tobacco I used.
So I told them Edgeworth.
Yours very truly,
A smoker of Edgeworth
(Signed) E. E. Boisvert

REPRESSION IN THE COLLEGE
HE college is regarded as the cradle of original 'thought; one of
its chief aims is to provide stimulation to those unique indiPerfect
viduals who have the ability to work, along original lines.
whatfreedom must be allowed the student to think,.read, and spak
out
ever, in his own opinion, is the truth. Johns Hopkins carries
have
this creed to perfection, but recently a number of other Colleges
underamong
movements
clamped down on all the so-called radical
graduates and faculty.
The New Student furnishes a number of instances of this policy
the
of repression. The University of Pittsburgh recently caused
Liberal Club of that college to disband. The important aspect of
unmitigated
are
memllers
this case is. not whether the Liberal Club
asses or budding geniuses, but whether the Univ;rsity has the right
to keep them from acting like unmitigated asses if they so desire. In
the reply to the Dean of men, the Liberal Club, in refusing to disband, made the following statement,"We consider a university campus as the fittest of all places for a free discussion Of any ideas,
theories, or practices that are current anywhere in the world.” That
is a clear statement of fact. If the University of Pittsburgh desires
only to instil a certain amount of rote learning into its student, it
would be better if it passed from the group of universities.
we are not upholding the ideas of the Liberal Club, but we do maintain that the members shbiild be allowed to hold and disseminate their
ideas.
Not only are some college authorities busying themselves in the
fight to suppress new thought and new customs, but outside organizations are entering the fray. The Woman's'Christian 'Temperance Union, for example. The branch of the W. C..T. U. located at
Fairmount, West Virginia, is vigorously campaigning against the
establishment of smoking rooms for girls at West Virginia University.
Repression by properly constituted authority is 'frid enough, but to
allow an organization extraneous to the campus dictate the practices
of the undergraduates is infinitely worse. ,And yet the W. C. T. O.
is making no unsuccessful fight.
This situation at West Virginia University illustrates very clearly
one of the great weaknesses of state educational institutions. The
Dean of a private college could very easily inform the W. C. T. U.
to mind their own business,and he would probably do that very thing.
But the heads of state universities are dependent on politicians for
their positions and the politicians in turn are dependent in part on
every fanatical group, such as the W. C. T.,U., which desires to
mix in college matters. The result is that the college authorities must
pussyfoot, must be conciliatory, and must spend their time listening
to foolish advice, unless they be extraordinarily capable and fearless
men.
No laymen would try to tell a sculptor how to carve a bust, 'or
teach a pharmacist how to fill a prescription, but a great number of
them, particularly women, think they know all about education and
they all are perfectly sure they know what, why, and how the younger
generation should think.

Instead of Greek letter organizations like American fraternities,

Verbindung. These organizations
have their own houses on University
campuses, similar to Ameircans, but
they have no secret ritual or special
+ badges to serve as recognition insignia. Membership in the Verbindung is conditioned on a unanimously favorable vote of the members, but instead of being rushed, it
ii considered good form on the part
of the student to petition membership in his own behalf.

The problem of American imperialism in the Carrabean region was
discussed in a paper presented by
R. D. Gregg, graduate student in
the Department of History, at the
weekly meeting of the Johns Hopkins Liberal Club, on Monday in
room 315, Gilman Hall.
Mr. Gregg pointed out the influence of financial interests in bringing about armed intervention in
weak countries like Nicaragua,
Haiti, and San Domingo. The desire on the part of American capi,
talists for field in which to invest
their capital at higher rates of interest, the necessity .of sources of
raw material, and the need for a
market in which the surplus products of our factories can be sold
were mentioned as the factors behind our "big-stick" policy toward
our southern neighbors.

EDITORIALS

According to Dr. Dean F. Smiley.
head of the Department of Hygiene
and Preventative 'Aledicine at Cornell University, the health of college students trends downward from
the time they enter, colleges as
freshmen until they leave. Dr.
Smiley explains this by saying that
each year that a man is in college
he takes less and less care of himself. The doctor his arrived at
three causes for this. The first is
that the influence of hnme and
mother is usually strong for good
health habits and maiitenance. The
longer the student, is away from that
influence, the less he feels its effect.
Secondly, that student life has for
many years been notable for it neglect of the ordinary hygienic laws.
There are too 'many bull-sessions
lasting far into the night and morning and too many bouts'of excessive
drinking. Thirdly, says Dr. Smiley,
a fair number of college students
are attempting the physical impossibility of doing the work of two men,
living the life of a day laborer to
earn a living, and the life of a student to acquire an education.
We notice the fact that, sad as it
may seem, although Dr. Smiley has
told us our defects he has not suggested any means by which we may
better these conditions. ,

REPRESSION IN THE COLLEGE
HE college is regarded as the cradle of original 'thought; one of
its chief aims is to provide stimulation to those unique indiPerfect
viduals who have the ability to work, along original lines.
whatfreedom must be allowed the student to think,.read, and spak
out
ever, in his own opinion, is the truth. Johns Hopkins carries
have
this creed to perfection, but recently a number of other Colleges
underamong
movements
clamped down on all the so-called radical
graduates and faculty.
The New Student furnishes a number of instances of this policy
the
of repression. The University of Pittsburgh recently caused
Liberal Club of that college to disband. The important aspect of
unmitigated
are
memllers
this case is. not whether the Liberal Club
asses or budding geniuses, but whether the Univ;rsity has the right
to keep them from acting like unmitigated asses if they so desire. In
the reply to the Dean of men, the Liberal Club, in refusing to disband, made the following statement,"We consider a university campus as the fittest of all places for a free discussion Of any ideas,
theories, or practices that are current anywhere in the world.” That
is a clear statement of fact. If the University of Pittsburgh desires
only to instil a certain amount of rote learning into its student, it
would be better if it passed from the group of universities.
we are not upholding the ideas of the Liberal Club, but we do maintain that the members shbiild be allowed to hold and disseminate their
ideas.
Not only are some college authorities busying themselves in the
fight to suppress new thought and new customs, but outside organizations are entering the fray. The Woman's'Christian 'Temperance Union, for example. The branch of the W. C..T. U. located at
Fairmount, West Virginia, is vigorously campaigning against the
establishment of smoking rooms for girls at West Virginia University.
Repression by properly constituted authority is 'frid enough, but to
allow an organization extraneous to the campus dictate the practices
of the undergraduates is infinitely worse. ,And yet the W. C. T. O.
is making no unsuccessful fight.
This situation at West Virginia University illustrates very clearly
one of the great weaknesses of state educational institutions. The
Dean of a private college could very easily inform the W. C. T. U.
to mind their own business,and he would probably do that very thing.
But the heads of state universities are dependent on politicians for
their positions and the politicians in turn are dependent in part on
every fanatical group, such as the W. C. T.,U., which desires to
mix in college matters. The result is that the college authorities must
pussyfoot, must be conciliatory, and must spend their time listening
to foolish advice, unless they be extraordinarily capable and fearless
men.
No laymen would try to tell a sculptor how to carve a bust, 'or
teach a pharmacist how to fill a prescription, but a great number of
them, particularly women, think they know all about education and
they all are perfectly sure they know what, why, and how the younger
generation should think.

Instead of Greek letter organizations like American fraternities,
German students have clubs called
Verbindung. These organizations
have their own houses on University
campuses, similar to Ameircans, but
they have no secret ritual or special
+ badges to serve as recognition insignia. Membership in the Verbindung is conditioned on a unanimously favorable vote of the members, but instead of being rushed, it
ii considered good form on the part
of the student to petition membership in his own behalf.

The problem of American imperialism in the Carrabean region was
discussed in a paper presented by
R. D. Gregg, graduate student in
the Department of History, at the
weekly meeting of the Johns Hopkins Liberal Club, on Monday in
room 315, Gilman Hall.
Mr. Gregg pointed out the influence of financial interests in bringing about armed intervention in
weak countries like Nicaragua,
Haiti, and San Domingo. The desire on the part of American capi,
talists for field in which to invest
their capital at higher rates of interest, the necessity .of sources of
raw material, and the need for a
market in which the surplus products of our factories can be sold
were mentioned as the factors behind our "big-stick" policy toward
our southern neighbors.
